projects.title: X-ray Pulse Simulation & Inference (X-PSI)
projects.description:
End-to-end developer of X-PSI, now transitioning to lead developer.

A package (API & framework) for Neutron star X-ray Pulse Simulation and Inference.

A package that is being implemented by NASA’s NICER collaboration. Provides a modular, customisable framework for numerical likelihood functionality and for prior density implementation. The package interfaces with external libraries for Bayesian computation and provides a suite of numerical algorithms for image computation via relativistic ray-tracing.The package is natively CPU-based, and built from a mixture of high (object oriented) and lower-level code: C extensions for Python (via Cython) to optimize away severe performance bottlenecks. It implements several core Python packages for numerics and visualisation; uses concepts such as inheritance, various descriptors, generators, and context management; is parallelised for several scales of computing architecture; is documented with Sphinx, including Jupyter notebook tutorials; and is hosted on GitHub. Implements: Python, C, Cython, NumPy, OpenMP, GSL, MultiNest, PyMultiNest, mpi4py, Sphinx+markdown/reST, Matplotlib, GetDist, nestcheck, SciPy, emcee, SymPy.

profile_positions.description:
Development of computational techniques and open-source tools for modelling contemporary and near-future X-ray telescope data, and application to data acquired by NASA's NICER telescope installed on the International Space Station. Technical lead of a team performing millisecond pulsar parameter estimation given data from the NICER telescope.

I developed a framework for modelling space telescope data using computational statistics and published an open-source software implementation. I used this framework to publish first-author journal articles that were central to the primary science objectives of a NASA mission and were central to the extension of the mission lifetime.

Supporting a new research group focussed on X-ray pulse-profile modelling during a transition phase to ensure knowledge propagation (tutorials, code development, Q&A, discussions, collaboration). Supporting the wider X-PSI user base. Includes supervision of students at all levels and leading training workshops and sessions.
